page.title: 01The Docks
page.content: The town of Penarth is a result of nineteenth century industrialisation. Iron ore was found and processed in Merthyr Tydfil, a town twenty six miles inland to the north of Cardiff; the foundries were fired by the abundance of coal in the area. A canal and later a railway built by Brunel brought the iron and coal to Cardiff where a dock was built. By the 1850's there was an urgent need for more dock accommodation as by now Cardiff was the main iron and coal exporting port in the world. In 1856 the Ely Tidal Harbour and Railway Act was passed and in 1865 the Penarth Dock was opened. Cogan, the area adjacent to the new dock (03170172) grew from being a tiny parish of 28 inhabitants at the 1841 census to over 186 in the incomplete census of 1861.
